metadata.title: NiFe Alloy Nanoparticle with Hexagonal Close-Packed Crystal Structure Stimulates Superior Oxygen Evolution Reaction Electrocatalytic Activity

references.title: A  cc  ep  te  d  M  an  us  cr  ip  t Angewandte Chemie International Edition This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.  COMMUNICATION COMMUNICATION Hcp-NiFe alloy nanoparticle encapsulated in N-doped carbon shell (hcp-NiFe@NC) was successfully synthesized through a facile MOFannealing strategy. Benefiting from the crystal structure and electronic property, the hcp- NiFe@NC exhibits outstanding OER performance over the conventional fcc-NiFe@NC catalyst
author: J. Deng
D.H. Deng
X.H. Bao
Adv. Mater

metadata.abstractText: Tuning the crystal phase of metal alloy nanomaterials has been proved a significant way to alter their catalytic properties based on crystal structure and electronic property. Herein, we successfully developed a simple strategy to controllably synthesize a rare crystal structure of hexagonal close-packed (hcp) NiFe nanoparticle (NP) encapsulated in a N-doped carbon (NC) shell (hcp-NiFe@NC). Then, we systemically investigated the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) performance of the samples under alkaline conditions, in which the hcp-NiFe@NC exhibits superior OER activity compared to the conventional face-centered cubic (fcc) NiFe encapsulated in a Ndoped carbon shell (fcc-NiFe@NC). At the current densities of 10 and 100 mA cm, the hcp-NiFe@NC with Fe/Ni ratio of ~5.4% only needs ultralow overpotentials of 226 mV and 263 mV versus reversible hydrogen electrode in 1.0 M KOH electrolyte, respectively, which were extremely lower than those of fcc-NiFe@NC and most of other reported NiFe-based electrocatalysts. We proposed that hcpNiFe possesses favorable electronic property to expedite the reaction on the NC surface, resulting higher catalytic activity for OER. This research provides a new insight to design more efficient electrocatalysts by considering the crystal phase correlated electronic property. Metal alloy nanomaterials as promising functional materials have attracted a great interest in electronics, optics and magnetism, especially in catalysis. To date, numerous strategies have been successfully developed to modify the catalytic performance of metal alloy nanomaterials, such as control of size to optimize the amount of the surface of the active phase exposed; tune of shape to achieve the ratio of exposed facets which display different activities and selectivities; tailor of composition to fine-tune electronic structure to promote specific pathways. However, the study of tuning crystal phase structures of metal alloy nanomaterials is relatively less owing to synthetic challenging. In general, metal alloy nanomaterials could crystallize in the forms of face-centered cubic (fcc), facecentered tetragonal (fct), body-centered cubic (bcc), hexagonal close-packed (hcp) structure, and so on. The stacking mode of metal atoms in different crystal phase gives rise to distinct crystal structure and electronic property, greatly influencing intrinsic catalytic property of metal alloy nanomaterials. For instance, FePt nanoparticles (NPs) with fct phase possess a higher activity and durability than their fcc phase for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). PtNi alloy nano-multipods in hcp phase exhibit a superior catalytic activity for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) compared to their fcc counterpart. The fccAuCu alloy catalyst shows largely enhanced catalytic activity when compared with fct-AuCu alloy for CO oxidation. NiFe alloy is one of the most promising candidates to expedite kinetically sluggish oxygen evolution reaction (OER) owing to its low cost and intrinsic catalytic activity. And great efforts have been taken to fabricate NiFe alloy through tailoring its composition and combining with various carbon materials for a better OER activity. However, all the NiFe alloys in these materials are typical fcc phase. Therefore, achieving the crystal structure control of NiFe NPs highlights a new way to explore an optimized OER catalyst. Nevertheless, synthesis of an unusual crystal phase of NiFe alloy remains great challenge. Herein, we put forward a simple strategy to synthesize hcpphase NiFe NPs. In this preparation procedure, we employed different content iron ions adsorbed microporous metal organic framework [Ni3(HCOO)6]∙DMF (Ni-MMOF) as precursors. After annealing these precursors under chemical vapor deposition (CVD) condition with hexamethylenetetramine (HTMA) at 400 °C, three samples with different Fe/Ni ratios hcpphase NiFe NPs encapsulated in N-doped carbon (NC) were obtained and denoted as hcp-NiFe@NC, hcp-NiFe@NC-1 and hcp-NiFe@NC-2. The NC shell can protect the NiFe NP from the harsh electrolyte and accelerate the catalytic reaction on NC surface. Surprisingly, hcp-NiFe@NC significantly improves the OER catalytic activity, exhibiting unexpectedly low overpotential of 226 mV at 10 mA cm in 1.0 M KOH electrolyte and excellent durability after 35 h operation at the current density of 20 mA cm. The competitive activity and excellent durability of hcpNiFe@NC show its great potential to replace precious metal catalysts in future practical application. The hcp-NiFe@NC was prepared through annealing the corresponding precursor of Fe@Ni-MMOF (the detail information can be seen in Figure S1 and S2). To quantify the proportion of Fe and Ni in NiFe NPs, inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-MS) was applied and determined the atom ratio of Fe/Ni was ~5.4%. The crystallographic structure of NiFe NP was preliminarily confirmed by powder Xray diffraction (XRD). As shown in Figure 1a, all the diffraction peaks can be indexed a typical hcp structure (space group: P63/mmc) and no singal of other metal phases are present. Rietveld refinement based on the observed XRD pattern was conducted and the calculated pattern well agrees with the tested one (reliability factors, Rwp is 2.978 and Rb is 2.613). And NiFe NP posesses a unit cell of a=b= 2.64851 Å, c= 4.3423 Å. Figure 1b displays scanning electron microscopy (SEM) image of hcpNiFe@NC in a large view, suggesting numerous sphere-like nanostructures. Further transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images (Figure 1c and 1d) clearly show each uniform [*] C. Wang, H. Yang, Y. Zhang, Prof. Q.
